Things VCs will want to know before they invest in your company:VCs want you to demonstrate that there's a big market for what you're selling, and big bucks being spent in that market.VCs want you to be able to explain how you are going to use their money.VCs will want to know about the market for the product or service you're selling.
More than that, they will want to know that it's a big market.Why? VCs are in it to help you grow, and big markets support growth.Not only are big markets more stable and less inclined to volatility, they are also able to support the operations of multiple growing companies.
And if the market is growing, even better. That will give you a tail wind.On the flip side, if the market you work in is too small, there may not be room for enough growth for the investor to get a return on his or her investment.VCs want you to show how your product is different from what's out there. What makes it unique?There are several ways to stand out.Product differentiation: You've got something completely different (and hard to replicate).Process differentiation: You are selling a new, more efficient way of doing things.Price point differentiation: You have found a way to sell a product or service for less or for more (i.e. premium pricing).Super niche differentiation: You've found a market that's a particularly good fit for you.The Five Cs are:1. CMRR, ARR, & ARRR â€“ Committed monthly recurring revenue, annual recurring revenue, and annual run rate revenue; 2. Cash flow â€“ Start with gross burn rate and net burn rate, then hopefully turn to free cash flow over time; 3. CAC â€“ Customer acquisition cost payback period. 4. CLTV â€“ Customer lifetime value. 5. Churn & renewal rates â€“ Logo churn, CMRR churn and CMRR renewed. Investors simply looking for a return often develop a philosophy nonetheless â€“ usually around their past ability to pick winners. For Details Please Chk My Blog: Google Arijit Bhattacharyya and see the blog section, link is in comments

The BMA’s recent update has sparked fury across healthcare.

Are walk-in GP appointments really not safe?

Recently, the BMA announced something that has landed it in controversy.

They said:

That poor ventilation-

Means walk-in GP appointments are not safe for patients.

The risk of COVID is just too high.

Critics have claimed that:

Consulting patients over Zoom would lead to more people diagnosed later than normal.

This comes on the back of the recent NHS mandate:

That all patients have the right to see their family doctor in person.

Karol Sikora, a medical expert, said:

‘It makes sense if the NHS is in crisis but the crisis has gone now.’

I personally believe a hybrid system for consultations would be a better idea.

But what about you:

Do you think walk-in GP appointments are safe for patients?

Back in February, I set my countdown clock to wind down a career that spanned a wonderful 33 years at Easter Seals Ontario and RBC. At RBC, 25 years and ten roles later, I have had a full career with so many opportunities to meet and learn from numerous leaders and peers, inside and outside of the bank. It’s been a privilege to be trusted several times over to lead teams and be a mentor. I’ve also had the opportunity to volunteer at organizations like Ascend Canada and March of Dimes, and with more free time coming up, I’m looking forward to pouring more energy into the causes so dear to me. These last 33 years wouldn’t be even remotely possible without the support of my wife, Jayshri and my daughters, Vanisha and Veena. They have been with me through the lows and highs and always believed and stood by me. I cannot thank them enough. If I’ve learned anything over these years – and I’ve been asked a few times since the countdown clock began – here are a few principles I’ve lived by for life and career: ·      “Think like a shareholder” is one of my go-to pieces of advice. If you put the company first over any person, line of business, or platform, you will consistently make the right decisions.    ·      For your career: your manager is the most important person in your network and don’t underestimate the power of a development plan. ·      Be generous with your time to others, volunteer and give back to your cause or community – and don’t expect anything in return. More than anything, I’ll look back at my time with RBC and Easter Seals and remember all the colleagues that became friends and the many things that we achieved together -- far too many to list (nor do I want to miss any!). I will forever be indebted to all of you for the experiences and conversations we shared.  Thank you for making my life richer and I hope our paths cross again. Until then, stay safe and healthy.

Today, I begin my new role as a Partner in EY’s Consulting practice. I am privileged to be part of such a great leadership team, and thankful for the support I’ve received from my mentors, colleagues, clients and family. Looking forward to the next chapter!

It really saddens me when I hear of people being forced back into the office because it suits their employers. Haven’t people proved themselves this past 18 months? Traditionally home working or remote working as we now call it was always for the lucky few. And by lucky few you had to have had an illustrious career with lots of rewards or grafted your proverbial ‘nuts’ off to massively overachieve every single KPI & then some. Just to prove you were worthy enough or should I say trusted enough to work from home. Fast forward to 2020 when the pandemic hit & the Government forced businesses to allow their staff to work from home. With little notice & in a lot of cases very little support, your staff went home & did their jobs. Often juggling their work load with home schooling their kids & often looking out for sick family members. How working parents have survived this last year is nothing short of herculean. Yet here we are 18 months later telling people they have to come back. Telling them they can’t have a blended return to the office. Telling them they can’t take annual leave. Telling them they can’t go on the holiday thats been moved 3 times already because the Government changed their destination to amber. It’s not fair, it’s not supportive & it’s not really justifiable. A massive shift has taken place, people have been through so much during this time. They know they won’t get this time back with their families, & they know they can do their job no matter where they are & what life throws at them. So please, stop putting people under more pressure & stress just because it’s suits you. You are creating a toxic workplace & you will loose good people. Let me know your thoughts on this? Have you heard any examples of this from friends or colleagues?

The amount of remote jobs is growing, but the number of people looking for these jobs is growing faster.

The good news for remote job seekers: Employers are starting to realize that offering remote positions is a good way to compete and attract the best talent.

Companies are also starting to offer remote roles for lower-level positions, so you no longer need to be as experienced to land a remote role.

However, there are still far more job seekers wanting remote roles than actual remote roles.

So if you want a remote position you need to get creative in how you approach these companies. Networking and approaching hiring managers directly is essential.

For anyone interested in the trends and topic, I recommend the article below. It was an interesting read.

Goodbyes are hard, and June has been full of them for me. I left two jobs that I loved this month. I’m excited to post about the incredible opportunity I accepted, but today I wanted to just share kudos about the awesome places I sadly had to leave to make it happen. mBank will always hold a special place in my heart. Because of my roots in Manistique/Marquette, it is full of countless former classmates, colleagues, and neighbors. My first day with Katy bringing me around to introduce me to everyone, I already knew most of them! Funny enough, the one department that I didn’t know anyone was IT. That quickly changed as everyone went from strangers to the best “work family” I’ve had. I can’t thank Jake enough for giving me the opportunity. I can’t thank Ryan enough for being the best mentor/safety net/partner-in-crime. CJ, Hillary, Jer, Joshua, Kurt, and Myra— I’ll miss you all. Leaving was heartbreaking. Acquisitions are a reality of banking, and change is part of that. For many non-customer facing roles, this meant frank discussions about moving. I have found that us Yoopers are hard-headed about many things, and one of them is leaving the UP. We’re all here for a reason, be it family, nature, or just the fact that it’s “home.” I wish those who are able to stay on the very best. I know for myself and many of my peers, seeking local or remote roles was the right choice for us and our families. Which brings me to Hagerty. I was thrilled to accept an offer to stay in the UP and remotely join their Incident Response team. My recruiting process with Tiffany was amazing. Hagerty has received national “Best Workplaces” accolades, and it’s easy to see why. Their embrace of remote work shows what a forward-thinking organization they are and the talent they’ve built is staggering. Once I was able to meet the Security team, and especially my manager and peers in IR, to say I was blown away would be an understatement. Knowing I found a place I could be happy after mBank was a relief. I envisioned a long future there— but life happens. Before the ink was even dry on my offer letter, I received an opportunity that is a huge leap for my career and my family. If you want to see the character of an organization, look at how they respond to tough news. Every single person I dealt with understood/supported my decision, even in the face of a difficult situation. To any of my contacts looking for work— this place is the real deal. Check out their open positions and follow them for future roles— they’re growing fast. Leaving there on such short notice was one of the hardest decisions of my professional life. In the near future, I’ll update my LinkedIn and post about my new role, but I wanted to take the time today to just thank these two incredible organizations. Wishing everyone at mBank and Hagerty the best, and glad to have crossed paths with all of you. Great people make the best workplaces what they are, and both places are overflowing with great peopl

We take a look at an article on why npm audit is broken, check out the AppSumo 2 day sale, a new query language for Wikipedia, look at some important changes to Git and why not, I struggle through the JS is weird test with you.

NPM and the Boy Who Cried Wolf

NPM, the tool that is installed with NodeJS...which most web developers use everyday has a false positive approach that creates a 'boy who cried wolf' problem. This great article from Dan Abramov is a deep dive into why that's a problem and potential fixes.

AppSumo Day Sale

This is a limited time deal, but the site is always awesome. AppSumo has a lot of up and coming apps often offered with lifetime deals. I've found so many useful apps here like Publr and Switchy. They have some specials that are set to last only for a couple of days.

Wikipedia QL

This npm project is a tool for querying Wikipedia. It's a NodeJS module that uses the Wikipedia API to retrieve metadata in an easy to digest JSON format. It runs on and returns easy to part JSON data. I like that at the end of the NPM project it shows some reasons why this is a better approach than other solutions provide by and for Wikipedia.

Git Restore and Switch

There's been some recent changes to Git, the most popular version control system for web developers. The git checkout command had been doing the work of switching to commits and branches as well as restoring the state of commits. That work has now been split into two different commands, git restore and git switch.

JS is Weird

I'm not big on quizzes...they bring back old memories of bad teachers, but I really think you should take this quiz. It's full of questions about JavaScript's quirkiness, so this isn't about learning useful code for your next project. and the best part of the quiz is not the questions, but at the end, the site provides thorough explanations of why the developer chose to write his own query language.

Today I’m delighted and excited to say I’m retiring.

Last week I resigned from Cloudflare, a truely great company and one I would not leave to join any other in this industry right now. I had a short but enjoyable stay there and would recommend them, both as an employer and a vendor, to anyone.

However, if this last 18 months has taught us anything it’s that if you have plans, you’d best get on with them, as you never know what’s round the corner! Dianne and I have lots of plans so……

I’ve been very fortuante in my career to work for some great companies and I’ve worked with, and learnt from, many talented people along the way.

Those who know me well will know that personal relationships and the social aspect of work has been very important to me. I’ve been lucky enough to make many friends along the way. One of my goals in retirement is to catch up personally with many who I haven’t see for a while. Look out you may be on my hit list??

This industry and the people in it have given me so much over the years and I’ll always be grateful to those who’ve helped me along the way. It’s also been fun, so thanks to all the fellow party animals out there to. It’s been a blast!

I have many plans for retirement including getting my golf handicap down, some serious travelling when things settle down, and moving down to Cornwall early next year with Dianne. The party animal theme will, of couse, continue unabated ??

Good luck to you all, and I hope to cross paths again with many of you in the near future.

Stay healthy and happy

We hear a lot of chatter in business and society today pertaining to respecting people, but so much of it is just frivolous words that vaporize quickly.

“Respect for People” extends to employees, customers and suppliers in a way where everyone’s position and situation is important when changes or improvements are being considered.

It’s not about mandating some ‘secret sauce’ software solution or management initiative that creates grief for the end-users!

Everyone must benefit from the change! It cannot be just some half-baked initiative/idea coming from one group/department that needs to hit some silly internal goal, without respecting the other people who may be negatively affected.

Begin by asking this question: “Are our customers, employees and suppliers penalized by the recommended changes?”

Overthinking, crippling nerves, sick stomach - all the symptoms of a fear of public speaking ??And the last month has given me an overdose of all of these. You see in January I decided 2021 was the year to move my public speaking to the next level. So I joined the Professional Speaking Association to give me the push I needed. And every year the PSA runs the prestigious #SpeakerFactor competition, the annual hunt for emerging professional speakers.  So this weekend I stepped up to the challenge and put myself on a (virtual) stage in front of an audience of professional speakers – folk that make their living from keynote speeches delivered all over the world. Way out of my comfort zone ??And yes, I will write it down. I won! I am the Winner for Ireland of Speaker Factor 2021 for the Professional Speaking Association.  ??My talk only took 5 minutes, but those 5 minutes were packed with the generosity, experience and expertise of too many people to name.  My fabulous work wife Sarah Travers, my client Brian Law and all of my family and friends stepped up. They’re there for me always and any time I ask. And from within PSA, an organisation that I only joined six months ago I am humbled at the generosity of those PSA members that shared their time and experience.  Jackie Handy FPSA FREC and Eamonn O'Brien, Next-Level Business Storytelling Expert are legends. And Steve Bustin’s Critique Club is something I would recommend to anyone looking for robust feedback to develop as a speaker. For her encouragement and support, PSA Ireland’s Denise Fay - Community Builder has been the rock that kept us all together. And for THE conversation that started it all off, I’m very grateful to Amy Rowlinson.To the rock that she’s become in my life, my fabulous PSA accountability buddy, Eileen Fleming, Thank You!! Eileen and I met for the first time in January at PSA Ireland and we now meet every single week to keep one another accountable for our goals and ambitions. I was one of an amazing line-up of Speaker Factor contestants. If you’re in the business of organising events, I recommend you connect with them. There was powerful emotion and advice and life experiences being shared in the room – your audiences will be moved. Aisling Brennan Denise Brannick Jean Evans - Networking Architect Aoife Gaffney Patrick Mercie Kate Rooney  The OnLegs Agency Liz ValloorWhat an experience.  My biggest takeaway was managing performance anxiety, so I updated my blog with what I learnt. I hope that you might find an idea that helps you the next time you decide to step up and do something that scares you…..   Link in the comments belowHave a great week.Paul Davis - Life Purpose and Business Coach Andrew Dobbin Colm O'Brien Lynda Shaw Barbara Moynihan Stuart Harris Andy Lopata #publicspeaking #presentationskills

Three months into my new role at Transport for NSW and I have embarked on maternity leave. Commencing a new role six months pregnant was a daunting prospect but my Executive Director and team have been incredibly supportive from the get go. From day one, I have been congratulated on my pregnancy and flooded with support. I have loved every second in my new role and relish the opportunity to positively impact our customers every day. I have never felt so motivated and whilst I'm looking forward to a few months off with this little guy, I am eager to return & make a difference. A shout out to Transport for NSW and my Maritime team for welcoming me so openly. I feel fortunate to encounter an employer who doesn't just talk diversity & inclusion but lives it. My experience has taught me that pregnancy shouldn't hinder your career. If you are expectant and considering changing roles or a promotion - take the plunge! And if you're looking for a challenging and rewarding career, in an organisation that fosters career progression, development and flexibility, I highly recommend Transport for NSW.#transportfornsw #nswmaritimeMark Hutchings Yvonne Hughes

*Book recommendation* Bomber Mafia, by Malcom Gladwell.I was surprised how engrossing this book is. Although I like reading about military strategy, air power was never a topic that particularly interested me (hence, not a a pilot). But, Gladwell expertly tells the story of aerial bombing vs precision bombing, tying it to morality in war. Few strategists other than the Bomber Mafia Air Force generals saw air power for what it truly was during WWII- a capability able to drive strategic decisions in the war, including the end of WWII with the aerial dropping of nuclear bombs. Today there is no debate about how important controlling the air is. We use precision guided munitions in a plethora of military operations. Throughout the book I couldn’t help but compare air power in the first half of the 1900s to Information Warfare today (includes cyber, artificial intelligence, and all things extremely high-tech). As we continue to develop, hone, and demonstrate the power of Information Warfare, I look forward to it also becoming an intrinsic part of every military operation.  In ~20 years there will be a sequel called “Information Warfare Mafia”.

After 15 long months of submitting countless applications, interviewing fewer than 10 times, and receiving a slew of discouraging emails, "my time has finally come." I am truly honored and excited to join CWEA (California Water Environment Association) as their new Director of Education! CWEA's mission and this role align perfectly with my core values, background, and skills, and I look forward to taking CWEA professional development to the next level. I am excited to learn from and collaborate with Executive Director Jenn Jones, MS CAE IOM and her incredible team in developing and delivering topnotch education, networking opportunities, and resources for California wastewater professionals!I would especially like to thank a few people for their support during this challenging year, including my gifted career coach Michelle Carlen who kept me focused, positive, and confident. Her guidance and insights were invaluable. I am also grateful to my professional references who wrote recommendation letters and spoke highly of me (THANK YOU :). I also appreciate Brigette Hyacinth for her daily doses of wisdom and encouragement on this platform, urging us job seekers to know our worth and never give up. Last, but not least, I thank the Lord Jesus for this opportunity to use my skills to the fullest. Fellow job seekers, keep pressing on and don't lose hope — even after numerous rejections. It may take some time, but it will be worth the wait for your next employer to find you. God bless!

Last week I celebrated my eleven-year work anniversary which has made me a bit reflective. I have been thinking a lot about my journey over the past eleven years and about the concept of change. In 2010 I was a teacher looking for a career transformation, and at the recommendation of a great friend, I took a leap of faith with Aerotek. A whole lot has happened since then… I’ve become a wife and a mother (twice) within my time here. I have taken on six different roles over the years, along the way supporting several different regions, divisions, and business units. Today, I technically work for a completely different company (still under the Allegis umbrella) reporting into an incredible Corporate team. I’ve had the opportunity to travel to so many places and partner with so many incredibly talented individuals. I’ve made a ton of amazing friends and memories along the way. I don’t take for granted the personal and professional growth that has been fueled by being pushed, challenged, and supported over the past eleven years. I didn’t choose Aerotek in 2010 because of the name of the company. I chose our company because of what it stands for and because of the people. I chose this company for the opportunity to grow, and to have the privilege to develop others. All of that still stands true as I now support Actalent, an Engineering & Sciences services and talent solutions company. I’m proud to have the opportunity to coach and develop our people as a Manager of Sales Training. There has been a lot of change over the past eleven years, but every single one of them has created positive momentum. I can’t wait to see where this next chapter in our journey takes us."When in doubt, choose change.... there is nothing permanent except change. I alone cannot change the world, but can cast a stone across the waters to create many ripples" - Unknown#WeAreActalent #PeopletoPossible #StillGladToBeHere

Yesterday I shared the SBOM Minimum Elements publication from US Department of Commerce, NTIAContinuing on with the theme of Software Supply Chain Security, per the Cyber EO, National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) along with the National Security Agency were tasked with publishing guidelines recommending minimum standards for vendors' testing of their software code. Those guidelines are now published in the attached "Guidelines on Minimum Standards for Developer Verification of Software" The document describes eleven recommendations for software verification techniques. These include:- Threat modeling to look for design-level security issues- Automated testing for consistency and to minimize human effort- Static code scanning to look for top bugs- Heuristic tools to look for possible hardcoded secrets- Use of build-in checks and protections- "Black box" test cases- Code-based structural test cases- Historical test cases- Fuzzing- Web app scanners, if applicable- Address included code (libraries, packages, services) "To ensure that software is sufficiently safe and secure, software must be designed, built, delivered, and maintained well. Frequent and thorough verification by developers as early as possible in the software development life cycle (SDLC) is one critical element of software security assurance."#ciso #infosec #security #cyber #cybersecurity #publicsector #software #sdlc #devsecops #nationalsecurity #technology #softwaredevelopment #incidentresponse

Tomorrow The Marketing Leadership Masterclass comes to an end and what a wonderful experience it has been. If you are looking for courses to help you develop your leadership skills I highly recommend this course. Thank you to Helena Verellen for recommending it.Here are my top 3 takeaways:The importance of leading upwards: don't be a problem-finder be a problem-solver. Do what you're best at and manage your worst self.Chase distinctiveness: If you want to hire an amazing team focus on 2-3 distinctive things the candidates have.Thank you so much to Syl Saller CBE, Thomas Barta and, Oliver Bowie ACIM ACMI for such a wonderful experience.

#Learnlooklocate. KNOW YOUR #Genetic Risk!https://bit.ly/3eoKoTE Meet Sammie! She has the BRCA1 gene-she now has Stage IV #Breastcancer. She is a FIGHTER! Her story is going to help so many #people become more educated on the POWER of #genetictesting  and how it can help save a #life! Her BRCA 1 gene came from her father, but her dad was not aware that he had the gene until Sammie's diagnosis. Her dad now has Stage IV #pancreaticcancer  due to the BRCA1 gene. Her identical twin also has the #BRCA1 gene and because of Sammie's #diagnosis, her sister was proactive and got a double #mastectomy . Sammie's #family  has been touched by the BRCA gene in so many ways which is why together we want to share her story to help EDUCATE the world on how important it is to know your genetic risk!Genetic testing can help #doctors look for missing or defective genes. This information helps them know if a person, their partner, or #family member is likely to have certain medical conditions. Genetic testing is offered to those who are likely to have an inherited mutation based on personal or family history of breast cancer or ovarian cancer. If a gene mutation is detected, you and your doctor can work together to manage your risk. Normally, the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes protect you from getting certain cancers. But certain mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes prevent them from working properly, so that if you inherit one of these mutations, you are more likely to get breast, ovarian, and other cancers. You and your family members are more likely to have a BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutation if your family has a strong history of breast or #ovariancancer. #Researchers are continuing to study gene mutations that increase the risk of cancer and developing new #gene tests. If your gene test was done more than five years ago, your #doctor  might recommend testing again as newer tests continue to come out. The BRCA gene test is a #bloodtest  that uses #DNA analysis to identify harmful changes (mutations) in either one of the two breast cancer susceptibility genes — BRCA1 and BRCA2.People who inherit mutations in these genes are at an increased risk of developing breast cancer and ovarian cancer compared with the general population. https://mayocl.in/3kmHi6I#women #jewish #connections #anxiety #oncology #immunotherapy #healthcare #radiation #depression

Hiring your first VP of ESG to launch your ESG strategy? Looking for a ESG Impact Reporting Director to get your ESG disclosures in shape for regulators and investors?  So are 100s of other global companies. As an experienced executive of both an enterprise ESG strategy and a Green Financing business, here are my top 5 recommendations for hiring your first ESG leader - and how to ensure their and your company's success in the long-term: 1. Teamwork makes the (ESG) dreamwork: Hiring a leader is a great first step to kicking off your organization's first ESG strategy. But they can't do it alone. They will need two additional teams to ensure their and your organization's long-term success with ESG: a dedicated team to develop and execute the ESG strategy and a dedicated cross-functional advisory council with defined responsibilities to support the new ESG leader and strategy. 2. Link ESG and the core business at the hip: An ESG strategy doesn't exist in a vacuum, and it can't succeed without being embedded in a business' core products and services. Your Head of Business Line A and Head of Business Line B may not be sustainability leaders, but they will need to partner with your EVP/SVP/VP of ESG to create the business value for your company. 3. You're hiring a change management leader not just a technical green guru: Your new ESG leader will know (or should know!) the in's and out's of all the ESG acronyms including UNSDGs, PRI, GHG, LCA, TCFD, SASB and more. But you should also be hiring for a leader who will be able to navigate and lead fundamental changes in your business and culture.  4. Don't leave the new ESG leader flapping in the wind: On the note of change management, it's hard. Integrating ESG and sustainability principles is tough and perhaps even tougher than "traditional" changes implemented at a company since there is a new language and even a new belief system to adopt. Whether you're hiring internally or externally, make sure you, the CEO, the CFO and even up to the Board, back-up the new leader especially when they face headwinds.Last but not least: 5. Give the leader - and your organization - time to succeed with ESG: You can absolutely get your first ESG report out and respond to MSCI, Sustainalytics and other ESG rating agency surveys within the first year of the new ESG leader taking on the role. However, setting ambitious long-term ESG goals grounded in a deep understanding of your current baseline will take much longer. Shifting core products to generate real, defensible, positive environmental and social impact (plus financial value!) will not be realized until at least year three or longer.  Follow me for more insights on ESG + business leadership. Send me a LinkedIn message if you need help launching your ESG strategy and team. #ESG #sustainability #changemanagement #leadership #culture #business #esgintegration

Stagnation - defined as lack of activity, growth, or development.  As I sit and run "Powershell" (I call it Super DOS) on my PC to help thwart the latest threat to my Windows PC, and have been doing this since the 90's, this is the only word that comes to mind.  In our careers, if we look at the products we build and support, tools we use, how we direct our teams...change is how we grow.  I cannot count the number of situations I've been thrown in, where at the root of the problems pointed squarely to stagnation.So...I will highly recommend you run the change highlighted in this article, as this is yet another critical vulnerability on your Windows PC...stagnation.

You may have seen many researchers who are very talented, yet, not very productive. It is because there are many factors that play in success of a researcher in addition to talent. Amongst others, academic environment plays an integral role. Some of the important steps that can help in developing a significant healthy academic environment are;1. In postgraduate research, one needs to be critical and should develop a skill of looking at a phenomena from different viewpoints. I will recommend something which I did not really observe during my PhD in Malaysia. It is really awesome to surround yourselves by other fellow researchers on a daily basis. Have healthy discussions on different ideas. This can help you learn and look at things from various perspectives. It can also help you facing critique on your work and how to be critical on others’ work. 2. During my time in UK and US, I have observed that people from a department meet for coffee every day either in on-campus coffee shops or in the designated discussion areas in the departments. Researchers (PhD candidates and young faculty members) throw their ideas around and ask questions. People take an interest in others’ research and help each other out. I have seen great collaborative work originating from these coffee table discussions.3. Courage is another important part of a healthy academic environment. One must be courageous to admit that s/he lack certain skills or does not know the answer. One must show courage to ask questions either from their seniors or their supervisors. Remember, that great scholarly works originate from one silly idea.4. Except for a very few Universities, most of the universities does not have extensive coursework for PhD students. As a result, PhD students do not interact with one another. It is very important for the grooming of researchers to have informal interaction sessions once a week or once in two weeks. Remember, that most of the PhD students make a big mistake by trying to do everything on their own and never discuss their ideas with others including their supervisors.Considering all of these points, ask yourself if you have a healthy academic environment in your department. If not, are you willing to create one? Believe me, it has wonderful results.As always, good luck and God bless you all.Follow me on https://lnkd.in/g8jAzrf #researchbeast

#TechTipsWithDevinApp technology tip this week! I wanted to share a new app I started using this week (thank you Steven Quagliero for recommending) called CamCard. This app is perfect for people (like myself) who hate uploading 20+ business cards into the CRM after an event. With the app you are able to scan the business card and it will read all the information on the card. Then, you can upload all of the contact information into a csv. file that you can import into your CRM. With the basic account you can scan up to 500 cards and there is also a premium option available to export directly to CRM. This is a great technology tool for anyone in sales, business development, or anyone just looking to find any easier way to manage their networking. Happy Wednesday to all!#sales #business #technology #businessdevelopment #networking #software #crm #apptechnology

Putting climate at the top of the ESG Pyramid This thought-provoking piece does a good job of addressing one of the key questions swirling around the ESG space. "Does mitigating the climate crisis trump all other global financial issues?"  My opinion, a resounding yes. Let’s face it, if we fail to solve the climate challenge, then Life on Land (UN SDG#15) and Life Below Water (UN SDG#14) and in fact, many of the other UN Sustainable Development Goals (UN SDGs) really won’t matter. Each of the 17 UN SDGs individually is irrefutable, all make perfect sense and each one represents a critical building block in making the world a better place for future generations.  We must pursue the UN SDGs, however, this cannot be at the expense of failing the most urgent, overarching climate challenge before us.  Some have suggested that the global pandemic has provided respite for the environment as evidenced by improved air quality and reduced greenhouse gas emissions - and it has. But that is something of a ‘false-positive’ as most of the improvements noted have already been nullified as the world returns to pre-pandemic activity. The climate challenge is unique as there is no historical data to predict how it will play out, how bad it may get, and it is unlikely to follow any linear projections. We know and we are already seeing the frequency and intensity of extreme weather events increasing significantly. Scientists have provided us with very compelling data that strongly recommends we limit global warming to well below 2, preferably to 1.5 degrees Celsius, compared to pre-industrial levels (the Paris Agreement). To achieve the goals of the Paris Agreement, we need to bring global GHG emissions back down to 1980 levels by 2030, and thereafter to net zero around 2050.  We will reach net zero when the amount of GHGs we produce is equal to the amount we remove from the atmosphere,...... and we will reach 2030 in just over eight years from now! To say that time is of the essence would be a massive understatement. If we fail to meet the 2030 target reductions, then the challenge becomes exponentially more difficult and the probability of failure increases significantly.  Climate-indicators have never been clearer.  All the lights are flashing red! This is singularly the largest, most complex challenge humanity has faced and one that will require marshalling all critical resources in a tightly coordinated, never before undertaken, global scale. We can learn from history and look at examples of successful countries, companies, and individuals. In most cases, their success has come from maintaining a maniacal focus on a few key priorities, and in many cases, just one single priority. Climate needs to sit at the top of the ESG pyramid - with the UN SDGs acting in support. But as we know, pyramids have baffled scientists for thousands of years...#climatechange #climate #climateemergency #environment #sustainability #climaterisk #esgrisk

Happy Friday! Well at least for now it is not the Financial Stability Oversight Council that is conducting the meeting. The FSOC could designate stablecoins as systemically important and subject them to Fed. (capital intensive/bank-like) regulation. However, some stablecoins operate like money market funds and could be regulated by the SEC....but the SEC (with pressure from the Fed/Treasury) is planning to further tighten up on money market fund regulation in the near future.#cryptocurrency #risk #stablecoins #cryptocurrencies #cryptowallet #cryptotrading #moneymarketfunds #sec #banking #fintech Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will convene a meeting with banking and markets regulators on Monday to review the growth of so-called stablecoins, a kind of cryptocurrency whose value is tied to an underlying asset like the U.S. dollar.The meeting will include the President’s Working Group on Financial Markets as well as the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. The presidential working group includes the chairs of the Federal Reserve, the SEC and the CFTC.Treasury said the group will look at "the current regulation of stablecoins, identify risks and develop recommendations for addressing those risks." The meeting is a follow-up to a December report that the President's Working Group issued on stablecoins.“Bringing together regulators will enable us to assess the potential benefits of stablecoins while mitigating risks they could pose to users, markets or the financial system,” Yellen said. “In light of the rapid growth in digital assets, it is important for the agencies to collaborate on the regulation of this sector and the development of any recommendations for new authorities.”

“An investment in knowledge always pays the best interest.”—Benjamin FranklinLast week, I graduated with Honours from Leiden University College The Hague and thereby concluded my BSc. degree with a specialization in the areas of Governance, Economics, and Development. Reaching this point in my academic career has been both a rewarding and an inspiring experience which I trust will enable me to magnify my positive impact within, and beyond, my circles. One of the ways in which I sought to create a positive impact in the past year was through my research into the effect of COVID-19 on the subjective financial stress levels of students and young professionals in The Netherlands for my bachelor’s thesis. My findings, although inconclusive, suggest that particularly first-generation students seem to have been at risk of experiencing elevated levels of subjective financial stress as a result of the pandemic. In response to this, my recommendation to institutions of higher education in The Netherlands, and Leiden University’s Faculty of Governance and Global Affairs in particular, was to provide scholarships with an element of financial coaching to the affected students.However, this achievement does not yet mark the end of my journey in academia. I am excited to announce that, following Benjamin Franklin’s wisdom, I will continue to broaden my expertise by pursuing a MSc. in Business Administration at the Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University in September. Moreover, with RSM’s focus being on the development of business leaders that can become a force for positive change, I believe to have found the right fit and I am looking forward to the commencement of the program.

You need to figure out how you are going to fund your mini-retirement. It’s common to save money to cover your expenses for the period of time you expect to travel. Another option is to develop passive income that can cover your expenses while you travel.Look at your recent credit card statements to see what recurring or subscription payments you can cancel while you are traveling. Make sure you have online payment options for everything else. I’d highly recommend automating your finances as this makes everything a lot easier. Check out Episode 35 for a full guide to automating your finances.You can leverage what you already own to create passive income to fund your mini-retirement. Since you’re only taking a short break from work, you might not want to sell everything you own to travel the world forever and you might still want to hang on to your house and your car.To make money on these while you’re away, you could rent your car to other travelers on Turo and rent out your house or sublet your apartment to a long-term renter, or to short-term renters on AirBnB.If you’re curious about how to afford a mini retirement, listen to Episode 43 ?? https://lnkd.in/dTN7mPs

Even if you are a beginner, I would highly recommend you to start blogging ASAP. Don't think about SEO, Ranking, even sounding smart. Just start because until you write 10-20 blogs, you won't become better.Here is how to get started ?? ??? Selecting Platform :1. WordPress (Difficult) - Need to build a website from scratch and research plugins2. Custom Website (Difficult) - Need to build the website from scratch3. Medium ( Easy ) - Famous for writing all types of blogs. Just need to sign up4. Dev.to ( Easy )- Famous to get started with tech blogs5. Hashnode.com ( Easy ) - Famous to get started with tech, programming blogs??? What to write: This is where most people get stuck, I do agree that everything that we know is already available over the internet, but that is not stopping others from writing, and it should not stop you as well. The easiest way to find a topic about blogging is via daily routine, write about your recent bug fix, what was your problem, how you solved it, what methods you tried, etc.Try to focus on one task at a time? Plan content : Don't worry about SEO for the time being. because good content always finds its way up. Take pen and paper and write down bullet points that'll act as header. e.g. - What is Javascript, Why to use ES6, etc. Once done, then fill content in bullet points. At this point don't think about sounding smart, grammatical things. Focus more on backing your blog with research facts, figures.?? Publishing : Once the first draft is written, go away from it at least for 6 hours, and then take a look at it again, you'll automatically see things that are not important, or things that are missing, grammar that can be corrected, etc. Sharpen the blog accordingly and publish it???? Comment down the recent blog you wrote, ???? Share with your developer friends #programming #content #blog

Here another management annoyance I have seen so often; hiring an ex-colleague by the boss.Six times in my career I changed company, with the last five in senior management roles. I _never_ hired someone from a previous company into my new team.While it may appear to be a safe bet to hire an ex-colleague and it may give you a short-term win; it is risky business, so be careful!1) Successes from the past are no guarantee for the future.The rehire may have done well in your previous company, but success is depending on so many elements and bringing in that person into your new company with new values and a different culture will expose him to new challenges and it is by no means said he/she will shine again. 2) The new hire is in an odd positionThe whole team knows he/she is a buddy of the boss and the team will be confused how to deal with him/her. The person usually has a direct communications channel with the boss and the team will naturally avoid him in discussions about the boss, afraid this will get leaked. Poor guy, or girl....3) The boss is not objective to the personAs this is a 'boss-hire' you will see the boss cannot look at the person with independent eyes and may miss issues the new hire causes in the team. The boss will be inclined to protect his 'man'.4) The invasion of the job snatchers!Hiring a single individual from the past may have is risk, hiring several from the previous company may completely destabilize the team. The boss is now bringing in his own army, the rest realize they are being side tracked and will get demotivated.Before you know you will see valuable old-time team members leave.So what???Your safest bet is to just _not_ do it. Only exception would be when in a start up where you have to build a team or complete new team from scratch.Companies should have a no-hire policy for Senior Managers to hire from their previous company. It is a recipe for disaster!Companies often have rules man and wife can't work in the same team, why not also apply that in this context?Note, peers recommending ex-colleagues into suitable roles is if course ok. Especially if the hiring team has no previous work experience with the person and is unbiased.Finally, if the company does allow this poor practice, and the boss is considering hiring an ex colleague into a senior rule in his team, he/she should completely disconnect him/herself from the process and leave the interviews and assessments to others. With the boss in the room you create a biased process where it will be very hard to have an open independent discussion. My advise, if you struggle for talent it's best to put all focus on your existing team and support them in their development. Trust me, your focus and your commitment to them will result in a huge payback in company loyalty. Don't fall into the re-hire trap!Thoughts?#companyculture #managementstyle #donotrehire

?What’s the bravest thing you’ve ever said?? As a recently published author , I’m often asked what my favourite business book is. In fact, right now it is ‘The boy, the fox, the mole and the horse’ by Charlie Mackesy.  As you will know if you’ve read it, it’s beautifully written and accompanied by wonderful hand-drawn illustrations and centred around a journey of friendship, love, resilience, vulnerability and compassion.  It is not technically a business book, of course, but resonates far more than many I have read. ?I recommend it as one of the best human-centred leadership books for dipping into, to find inspiration and get to the heart of what really matters. ?Especially now and especially as leaders everywhere are being challenged to demonstrate more heart, more empathy, more EQ , more vulnerability, more compassion, more courage etc. In fact, the very same as their people, as we emerge from a global pandemic, years of transformation and into a more unpredictable future. We are stronger together and all facing an uncertain decade ahead. Leaders, managers, teams, customers, partners, families, friends. These human-centred traits are the power skills for now and this book illustrates the point beautifully, deeply and with a lasting imprint. One of the quotes I love to use is: ?‘What’s the bravest thing you’ve ever said?’ asked the boy. ‘Help’, said the horse?It is full of snippets like this one, which highlights the opportunity for coaching, self-learning personal development and open discussion at all levels and especially for many leaders today. We all need a little help, a little inspiration and a lot of ?heart? - even at the very top. Maybe you can dip in, take a look and be inspired for the week ahead. Happy Monday! #leadership #inspiration #leaders #people #loveandrespect

In the last few months, I have learned and immersed myself in Organizational Design for Digital Transformation.This was done through taking an MIT online course by that name and reading the book "Designed for Digital" written by Jeanne W. Ross  (who also runs the online course), Martin Mocker and Cynthia M. Beath. This is very hot recommendation (Blog post in Hebrew in first comment) for all those trying or working in the Digital transformation of big old companies – which is the focus of this content. Three big takeaways from the book (amongst many others):1.      The difference between Digitize and Digital: this articulation is critical as they are both called today a digital transformation, but they are very different and require different elements, processes, discipline and more. Digitizing is an enhancement of current offerings and process with digital technologies – more efficiency, scale and outcomes. Digital is the rapid creation and innovation of new value offerings to your customers leveraging digital technologies. 2.      A framework for change: The Authors lay out a very clear Lego brick framework in order to transform. Five bricks that need align to the organization, its vision and current state:  Operational Backbone, Shared Customer Insights, Digital Platform, Accountability Framework and External Developer Platform. 3.      Big old companies: In healthcare big old companies rule, and this is why this book is so relevant, it doesn’t look at quick and nimble startups but the heavyweight, sometime not so sexy organizations and makes it easy to relate and understand it is possible. For me this book and course rang many bells inside my head and that’s why I am so happy to recommend. #digitaltransformation #innovation #corporateinnovation

Ever taken a road less travelled?It can be a lonely journey without the right people around you.Life is hard enough - build a team that can help you navigate the twists and turns. I have been fortunate to work with some world leading teams including the oil and gas industry team of Safety experts I led that developed the IOGP life saving rules. Over 10 years ago we took 20 years of fatality data and discovered the main causes of fatalities in the industry which led to the first version of the rules. Recently they were updated https://lnkd.in/euYvXyFHow the rules are determined and implemented makes a huge difference to the uptake and compliance and consequently the number of fatalities. If you need help DM me any time, any industry not just O&G.The IOGP has an excellent free library of standards and recommendations built on hard lessons. Worth a look even if you are not working in oil and gas. Any guesses where this road is ?#riskmanagement #teamcoach #imcominghome

Chuffed to be ranked as a top recommended family law barrister in Spear's Magazine - one of only about 30 barristers practising family law in this jurisdiction and with some stellar former colleagues at 1 Hare Court as well as others who I also now instruct for company! It’s so pleasing to be recognised but even more pleasing that my amazing solicitor colleagues in the Forsters LLP family and private client teams are also so highly rated (and I’ve no doubt the rest of the team will all be recognised in the years to come, what an amazing team). If I think back to what life two years ago looked like when I left the independent Bar - depressed, burned out and on the verge of doing something entirely different, to now (helping to manage and grow our lovely & busy team, collaborating and learning every day, in a firm that really values its people, and happily married with a settled and well balanced life) I feel so blessed. When I left the Bar people told me I was “brave” / “are you mad?” etc. Sometimes in life you have to properly shake things up to grow again both as a professional and as a person. It’s so ‘easy’ to continue doing something just because that’s what you have always geared towards even if you are down a blind alley from a well-being perspective. Personally I (mostly anyway!) now love developing long term relationships with, and resolving issues for, clients, and instructing former colleagues at the Bar to do the talking when necessary. It’s a tough gig. I’ve been there and have enormous respect for you. I’ll forever be in the debt of my firm for taking me, Somaya Ouazzani Legal Recruitment Specialist for identifying the match up, and Sandra Davis at Mishcons, the best solicitor I worked with consistently when I was at the Bar (among many brilliant others - you know who you are!) for making me realise my skill set could work in a law firm. But most of all Jo Edwards Rosie Schumm and Simon Blain for being the best and most talented (all also recognised in Spear’s) partners I could ever have wished for. I look up to you all. Thank you. Here’s to England bringing it home tonight! ????????#thankyou #team #legal #motivation #hnw #family

Has someone helped me get to where I am now?I feel very lucky to have developed a network of amazing women leaders in my life over the last decade. From Sarah Lewis to Meera Oak to Madison Killen and Diva Winje, AIA, LEED GA. I think having people to go to for career advice and perspective has been so helpful, particularly when faced with a fork in the road.At Magoosh, I would say that Melanie Oei and Jessica Wan have been my biggest mentors (outside of my own amazing manager Peter Poer as well as our CEO). Hearing their reflections on their career paths, listening to their experiences as a manager, and getting feedback and thoughts on the road ahead has been so helpful during challenging times.Are you looking for #mentorship?If so, I'd recommend looking for a couple specific traits:Sincerity + Vulnerability. -Advice I have found the most helpful at times is a past mistake or lesson learned. It takes vulnerability to share that with another human, so they learn from it. Finding someone willing to make those kinds of shares has been the most helpful.Curiosity + Active listening skills. -Some of the other best support I've received has not been in the form of advice but in the form of really, really good questions.-Asking insightful questions that push someone to think in a different way or take a new lens to the situation (e.g. if your best friend was in this position, what framework would you suggest they use here?) can be far more useful than hearing about some tangetially related circumstance.-While it would have been great at times to have had specific advice from a People Operations specific mentor who was in my field but 5-10 years ahead, that exact skill match is not always going to be available or in your network. Beyond that, having someone— who is not far along, who is your peer, who is in a different dept— but is really great at asking questions can be all the thought partnership you really need.In need of #career advice and don't know where to turn? Use LinkedIn! Send out a cold email! Worst case, you don't get a response and best case, you get some great thought partnership!

WANTED:  RELIABILITY & COMMUNICATION!!!The relationship between the architect and the design team is crucial for the success of any project or build.   Communication must be top shelf! Just as important as the relationship between the architect and the design team is the relationship with your manufacturer representative. You need them, they need you...or at least that's the way it supposed to work. But does your relationship sometimes seem one sided?  What happened?  I have been in the business for close to 20 years. 12 of those years working as a product rep for one of the largest manufacture in the flooring industry. I was really good at my job. I took pride in my strong relationships, which still remain strong today.I was not alone, however, there were a handful of other great reps considered to be excellent at their craft.  Those select few reps over the next decade became both good competition & respected friends.. Respected, because I noticed they were working just as hard as I was at perfecting their game.  They cared!Time went on, many of those great reps like myself were promoted and new reps were brought on board.Within the last year, I was looking to hire a few reps.  I reached out to some of "my friends" in the industry for some recommendations...I was shocked, in fact disappointed at what I was told. When I asked for recommendations...many of these industry giants said; "Honestly Brandon, I can't really recommend anyone"....not even one, I asked,..."No sorry, not even one"  I thought to myself, how very sad.  Times have changed and the talent pool is not the same as it used to be. The same can be said of many other fields. There are some great flooring contractors, who use the services of great installers...yet those installers are aging, and there doesn't seem to be many replacements, at least not lining up to take their place. It's a problem.Each company has to do a better job finding and developing talent.This is what I love about working for Urban Surfaces. We see our role as crucial to your success.  We are more than just a flooring manufacturer and distributor...We are servant leaders, forging relationships. We care!When it comes to phone calls...we call you back, when you need a  specification on a product(s), we send without delay. When designer's request a sample, we send it in a reasonable time and free of charge. We value relationship. It's a culture of care from the top down.#design #success #team #construction #communication #project #business #designers #community #work #love #culture #talent #architect #customerservice #branding #UrbanSurfaces

BTS: A look into how I practiced ?? & developed an Instagram Reel for my travel brand, Simply Briee.What have I learned about Reels?1. Keep it simpleI've developed Reels that included intricate transitions, multiple hair, makeup and clothes changes. I've also developed Reels that were super simple (like the Reel below). Guess what? The simple Reels that take about 15-minutes to complete have performed better than the Reels I took two hours to develop. 2. Be relatable & informativeI've stressed this many times: People love authenticity on social. The Reels that have performed well for me are also relatable and informative. They share insights (in a simple way) that new travelers may not have been privy to. My recommendation: Create simple content that your followers (& non-followers) will save & share with a friend or family member because it's relatable to them.3. Call to actionPeople like to be told what to do...well sort of. Empower your lurkers (non-followers) to want to follow & engage by using CTAs that make them feel like they are making the choice to follow you.Here's one of my favorite CTAs to use at the end of my Reels: Did you find this helpful? Follow [insert handle] for more [insert your content type]. #contentmarketingtips #socialmediaforbusiness #brandbuilding #instagram #instagrammarketingtips #instagramforbusiness #instagramreels #instagrammarketingtips #sociamediamarketing #socialmediamarketingtip #contentmarketing #businesstips101 #businesstipsforcreatives

Silo busting. The bigger the organization, the more of a threat #silos are to the #design team's #creativity, #productivity and #visibility.Training and support is needed to help the #team develop the capacity to overcome these challenges on both individual and organizational levels. For mine, I typically recommend they start with this great article from #harvardbusinessreview on four practices that enable effective interface #work that serve as good reminders:- Develop and Deploy Cultural Brokers—These are people who promote cross-boundary work in one of two ways: by acting as a bridge (possessing considerable knowledge of both sides and can figure out what each one needs) or as an adhesive (bringing people together, helping to build mutual understanding and lasting relationships).- Encourage People to Ask the Right Questions—Leaders show interest in what others are seeing and thinking and teach others to do the same by asking questions.- Get People to See the World Through Others’ Eyes—Leaders can regularly emphasize the importance of diverse expertise by setting up cross-silo discussions with customers, colleagues and other parts of the company and work at the top of the funnel by hiring for curiosity and empathy.- Broaden People’s Vision—Leaders can create opportunities for people to widen their horizons by bringing people from diverse groups together on initiatives and urging them to explore distant networks to tap into expertise outside the company and even outside the industry.Who’s a leader? Anyone who “takes the lead” and plays a role, regardless of what level they are in the organization. It’s the combined contribution that creates a tide that lifts all boats. Or breaks all silos, as it were.#leadership #culture

?? An important new book ?? about the Theory Of Constraints (TOC). Recommended for those involved in professional services, strategy, and information / I.T.: “Exceeding the Goal” by John Ricketts. For those that have, as I have, been following the development of the Theory Of Constraints for decades you will know that John Arthur Ricketts is the author of "Reaching the Goal" (2007) and was THE pioneer in the use of TOC in I.T. That first book was based on his long career in IBM as a Technical Strategist among other things. I consider that "Reaching the Goal" and now "Exceeding the Goal" are mandatory reading for those involved in I.T. and interested in TOC. He looks at the subject with a refreshing new angle on I.T. and TOC (a very important duo in 2021). The mix of ideas and his grounding in his extensive experience are very impactful. His case studies (he calls them "Adventures") are wonderful and make you laugh and cry.We all have our preferred authors, it is a matter of personal taste, and in the field of TOC in IT John Ricketts is one of my favourites. The topic of Agile is smothering a lot of other important trains of thought in I.T. Take a break for some fresh thinking. #strategy #information #technology #software #theoryofconstraints #goldratt

There was a lot of interest in my previous posting on Venture Idea Assessment. To facilitate rigorous use of this assessment tool we organize three workshops in different time zones as described below. The workshops are mainly pitch towards PhD students and researchers will be highly informative--and interactive--also for those considering use of the VIA measure in their incubator/accelerator/investment practice.We cap each session at 30 to make interactivity possible. You will need to register using the linked form. Welcome! - - -July 26, July 27 and September 3, 2021 (see times below)By Per Davidsson (QUT) and Denis Grégoire (HEC Montréal) What drives assessments of how promising a venture idea might be? How, why and with what consequences do such assessments vary across team members, helpers, investors, mentors, current and potential employees, and the general public? How, why and with what consequences do these assessments vary over time?  Researching these questions requires a clear concept and valid measure for distinguishing assessment of ideas from assessments of the people who pursue these ideas. To address this challenge, we wrote an article, recently published in the Journal of Business Venturing, where we develop the concept and validate a new instrument for measuring Venture Idea Assessment (VIA) across six empirical studies. To foster new research advances in this area and facilitate sound and rigorous use of this new concept and measure, we invite interested PhD students, scholars, educators, and practitioners to take part in an online Professional Development Workshop (PDW) we will be hosting (on the zoom platform). The 60-minute workshop will include a 15-min presentation of the concept's underpinnings and recommendations for using the VIA instrument, followed by 40 minutes of Q&A interactions between participants and the authors and a 5-min synthesis. To accommodate participants located in most time zones, we will host three workshops: Asia-Pacific-Far East: July 2615:00 (3pm) Australian Eastern Standard Time (UTC +10:00)07:00 (7am) Central European Summer Time (UTC +2:00)Americas: July 2717:00 (5pm) Eastern Daylight Time (UTC -4:00)Africa-Europe-Middle-East: Sept 0313:00 (1pm) Central European Summer Time (UTC +2:00)07:00 (7am) Eastern Daylight Time (UTC -4:00)   To foster meaningful exchanges among participants, we will limit participation to 30 individuals per workshop. We invite interested participants to pre-register their intent to take part HERE (or copy the link below into your favorite browser).https://lnkd.in/gsBs_zc For more information on VIA, please consult the article here (free access until August 7, 2021) We look forward to discussing with you the research opportunities afforded by our VIA concept and measure.Per and Denis #phd #entrepreneurship #research #opportunities #assessment #evaluation #accelerator #incubator #pitchcompetition

Koi Insurance:I’m looking for insuring one of my client’s Japanese Koi fish collection. Koi is a type of coloured carp that’s kept for decorative or ornamental purposes in outdoor ponds or gardens. See video. Koi breeding is a worldwide hobby today. There are many FB communities of Koi breeders in India as well. Mumbai Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj and Singapore Changi Airports have Koi ponds inside the terminal buildings. The risks to be covered:Total loss of fish due to any of the following named perils: ??Animal or predator attacks??Epidemics??Parasitic infections??Accidental pollution or poisoning??Malicious act by third parties??Fire and allied perils including AOG??Burglary and theft. Exclusions can be: ??Wilful injury, negligence, error or omission by the insured or his family members or servants ??Loss or damage caused by improper management, rough handling or during cleaning or change of water??Partial losses of any nature  ??Loss or damage caused by fluctuations of temperature or due to the physical and chemical status of the water, ph-factor or due to low water levels or asphyxia??Natural mortality??Clandestine sale or mysterious disappearance ??Permanent or partial disablement of any nature??Consequential loss arising in any way ??All types of transit losses ??Death occurring within 15 days from the inception of the policy.Valuation: For deciding on basis indemnity, valuation of the Koi can be done based on nature, type, size etc Currently, PSU insurers have an insurance product for fish cultivation or pisciculture. This covers commercial fish such as shrimp or tilapia. Unlike commercial fish insurance which has high moral hazard risk, Koi insurance will likely have low moral hazard as the breeding is done for more recreational and not commercial reasons. Physical hazards are mitigated by proper breeding practices such as installation of safety net over the pond, to ward off predators like cats, dogs, foxes or birds, maintaining water quality and adherence to recommended feeding regimen. Any Indian insurer is interested in developing a Koi Insurance Product to address my client’s requirement as well as exploring similar opportunities, please get in touch with me or write to me at hari@amicusbrokers.com.

Stanford University PRISM Postdoctoral Training OpportunitiesWe are thrilled to announce that the application is now open for our 8th PRISM Cohort! Stanford PRISM is a recruitment opportunity for late-stage graduate students from diverse backgrounds to explore postdoctoral training at Stanford.What is Stanford PRISM? PRISM (Postdoctoral Recruitment Initiative in Science and Medicine) is an opportunity for select late-stage graduate students from broadly diverse backgrounds to explore postdoctoral training at Stanford. PRISM gives you direct support with support and initiatives such as: interviewing with potential mentors, getting the inside scoop on postdoctoral training at Stanford from current postdocs, and even accessing professional development to score the best postdoc match for them! The purpose of this program is to encourage those who might not otherwise consider a postdoctoral position at Stanford to get a first-hand look at whether Stanford might be a good fit for them... Our goal is to match excellent trainees to excellent mentors at Stanford!This opportunity is open to all. We especially encourage those from backgrounds underrepresented in academia to apply, including communities such as but not limited to: African Americans, Latinos, Native Americans, Pacific Islanders, Filipinos, those with disabilities, those from FLI backgrounds, and those underrepresented on the basis of their gender identity, gender expression, and/or sexual orientation. Applications consist of an application form, a CV, a research statement, a recommendation from your graduate advisor, and the names of up to 6 potential mentors at Stanford.For more information on our program and/or to apply, please visit our webpage at:https://lnkd.in/edaQzSR Fall 2021 Dates for PRISM Cohort 8: October 13th-16th, 2021(Deadline to Apply for Cohort 8 = July 26th, 2021!)We hope to bring PRISM Cohort 8 to campus (in-person) for a 3-5-night stay on Stanford University's campus. The goal is for prospective postdocs to use that time to explore the training environment, meet with faculty, and get a feel for the community here at Stanford. Please Note: Travel will be dependent upon travel policies at that time... (If we are unable to host candidates in-person, a full complement of recruitment events will be offered virtually.) #research #medicine #science #students #education #highereducation #internship #training #opportunity #professionaldevelopment #career

“A World Health Organization expert advisory panel Monday issued two new reports recommending the implementation of global standards aimed at preventing unscrupulous, inequitable and potentially dangerous uses of Crispr and other gene-editing technologies.The reports call for efforts to develop global standards, the establishment of an international registry of gene-editing experiments and a way for whistleblowers to report concerns. Their release comes more than two years after a Chinese researcher triggered international outrage when he revealed that he had used Crispr to produce the first gene-edited babies.The committee, made up of ethicists, policy makers and lawyers, said in the reports that the use of gene editing had evolved dramatically since they set out in December 2018 to develop a governing framework and that recent successes in altering the DNA of people with lethal diseases had opened up ethical challenges.The reports described several scenarios that the proposed strategies might help prevent, including conducting gene-editing trials in low-income countries to develop therapies that would ultimately be too costly for all but the wealthiest ones to buy; unscrupulous clinics offering unsafe or ineffective gene-editing services to people desperate to overcome potentially life-threatening conditions; and the use of gene editing for enhancing traits such as athletic ability.“We want people to look at what is happening now and what we need to do to shape the way the research will proceed,” said committee member Françoise Baylis, a professor at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Canada, and an expert on the ethics of human gene editing.”

5 Tips to Attracting New Online Customers1. Improve Your Site's Search Engine Optimization (SEO)Search engine optimization is what helps your site show up in search engine results when people look for what you're selling. Optimization involves making sure your site's content includes the keywords and phrases people type into search engines.When you've got a keyword list, rewrite the related page's content to include the keyword at least three to four times."Sometimes the best way to find the most appropriate keywords for your website is to use a competitive analysis tool to study the websites of your competitors, "Try to figure out which keywords they are targeting so that you can target similar ones and find your way past those competitors."~2. Create Content Around "Long-Tail" Keywords"Long-Tail" keywords are terms with lower search volumes because they're very specific—the searcher often knows exactly what they're looking for.There will be lots of searches for a phrase like "pet supplies," but the term is so broad that you don't even know if it applies to dogs, cats, or guinea pigs. Instead, look for long-tail keywords that reveal the intent behind them."A phrase like 'buy 6-foot dog leash' is much more specific and the intent behind it is much clearer. While long-tail keywords will not drive as much search volume, they will drive more qualified traffic to your online store.After developing your long-tail keyword list, he recommends creating detailed landing pages for the products that fit those keywords, making certain that the text includes the appropriate phrases. Site visitors arriving on that page can then immediately add the corresponding product to their shopping cart.~3. Blog About Niche TopicsBlogging is one of the easiest and most effective ways to attract site traffic. When you write articles that incorporate your ideal customers' search terms, your site will show up higher in search results.By using the SEO research tool Ahrefs to identify keywords, and then writing helpful how-to or otherwise informative articles about the keyword topics.  You can increase your traffic by 1,000%."For example, if you search on Google for 'blonde roast coffee' or 'blonde roast,' you'll see that the number one article right now points to your website, not Starbucks,". ~4. Use Social Media StrategicallyRather than spreading yourself too thin across multiple social networks, focus on one or two that your target audience uses the most. Develop a mix of content that is useful, informative, promotional, and fun or entertaining, as long as it's in line with your brand personality. You can also use video to demonstrate or images to inspire.~5. Get Smart About Email MarketingBuild an email list by offering something of value that encourages people to add themselves to your list. Retailers often do that with a new-customer discount on the first order. Then stay in touch regularly with updates, information, and offers.

I will be shortly be hitting 10 years at LV.... which is a nice round figure to be leaving on! I've experinced a whole range of life events during my time there, formed great connections, many of whom are on my favourite people list and ones that I am still very much in contact with on a regular basis. The strength of LV has always been about the people that work there.The hidden job market really interests me so if you know anyone that would be open to having a chat about roles (or want to talk through about what they might need), please let me know!I have been spending a bit of time familiarising myself with the traditional job search process to explore what is out there. I'm really finding it interesting observing how the recruitment process works (and feels) from an end to end candidate perspective.  So far my best of breed process would look like this....1. Best job search - Otta.com - great layout, thoughtful and well written roles, doing things differently.2. A recruiter understanding the job requirement and creating an easy to read and encouraging job advert -  Mark Doherty at LV= GI.3. Transparency with contact details for the hiring manager. That goes to Bournemouth University - Donna Hornsby emailed me back within the hour with a very helpful response! 4. Most efficient and timely - Monzo Bank.5. Best pro-active feedback - Nationwide.6. Most improved - JPMorgan Chase & Co. - Strong emphasis on flexible working and removal of technical jargon!7. Best overall end-to-end experience - Nationwide Building Society Clear direction of travel from CEO, easy to use job search & application process, clear communication, insightful videos, transparent interview process and proactive feedback. Really engaging experience when connecting with employees like Richard James & Jon Hull who don't need to reply but show their passion for where they work.My summary so far? Things have moved on with job descriptions and less 'must have's' however the search and process is still quite focused on job titles - the work that Rob Baker, FCIPD, MAPP is doing fascinates me as I believe the future of work will be 'what canvas of skills' can someone bring. If anyone is interested in exploring this, get in touch!I have gained a really good understanding of the outplacement process - Eleanor Tweddell and Amanda Paradine are experts in their fields (check out Another Door) and Lee Hecht Harrison really offer a comprehensive offering with passionate and knowledgeable staff like Sally Ann Robertson. Christopher Ross has developed a brilliant concept in the Convoy Community so check them out or get in touch to find out more.Great to see the new people I have met along the way such as Frances Khalastchi fourishing and using their distinctive strengths and talents.Finally if you are in a similar position get in touch, I will always help where I can with recommendations or be there to listen.

Dear C-suite folk of companies of all sizes...I started using Excel over 20 years ago and for almost a decade of that time period Excel didn't change.  We had time to learn from our colleagues by looking over their shoulder.  This was OK.These days significant new functionality is appearing every 6 months and dramatic feature enhancements capabilities are appearing every couple of years.If you are happy to continue with inefficient daily work practices then stick with assumption that your staff "know" Excel. In my experience they probably learned Excel 5-10 years ago, or have learned from someone that learned it 15-20 years ago.   Their knowledge is likely out of date.  If you'd like the organization to be more efficient then staff should receive Excel Training every 3 years as a minimum.  This is a product they use all day every day, so every little improvement has a big impact.  My recommendation is to make sure that a "skills update" training course covers Tables, Power Query, Dynamic Array formulas, Pivot Tables and at least an overview of Power Pivot, otherwise look for another training provider.   Then for those people who have the "data gene" give them dedicated Power Query , Power Pivot and even Power BI training.  They'll love it and your organization will benefit from having these internal data champions in the team.I'm an Excel and Power BI Trainer so I've clearly got skin in the game here,  but that doesn't make me wrong.WynMicrosoft MVPExcel and Power BI Developer and TrainerOnce upon a time Chartered AccountantAccess Analytic Training:https://lnkd.in/gkqWWrW
